job_title: Consumer Service Advisor in Manchester, England
pros:
Helping people who need it is great
No weekend
cons:
Awful time pressures and everything is target driven, reducing the capability to deliver quality advice and empathy (a core value of CAB). The contradictions of values, ethos and the contractual demands is really frustrating.
You are a buffer between consumers and trading standards, a lot of consumers only want to talk to trading standards. Often apologising on trading standards behalf for no action being taken. 
Management are unresponsive and out of touch. They often lied and would pick on particular colleagues
Allot of my colleagues shared simmilar sentiment when it discussing management.
Management made everyone work in the central office during lockdowns, putting peoples health at an unnecessary risk. It was more than possible to deliver a telephone service remotely.

review_title: Experience will differ depending on where you are based.
pros:
+ Working with people who truly want to make a difference
+ Great training
cons:
-Managers: Do i need to say more? A lot of managers are power-trippy and love to micromanage your every movement. 

Again, your experience will differ depending where you are based. But majority of managers are pretty grim (heart is in the right place, but they have 0 people skills). 

-Lack of diversity: There is little to no BAME representation, majority white/het office workers.

pros: Flexibility and support from colleagues
cons: funding is not always stable

pros:
The people that work here are absolutely lovely. The work, although tiring, is often rewarding.  If you like helping people find solutions to their problems, this job is for you.
The team is extremely welcoming and laid back, and I felt very comfortable here. The training and support is excellent , and the pay isn't horrendous compared to other contact centre roles. 
Some career opportunities in other areas of the business. 
 The team make an effort to help each other out, and are always organising social events to keep everyone engaged and included. 
I would definitely work here again :)
cons:
Systems are outdated and frequently crash, which is difficult to manage when you're timed on calls. 
Pay isn't great, you'll be maxing out at £18,200 a year. The work can be very repetitive, and is often very busy meaning there is no break between calls. Repeating the same legislation over and over can drive you nuts. There is a 90 second WRAP time which is quite short, feels a little school like. Would get this in any contact centre though .
Customers frequently distressed and rude, you will need to be able to diffuse emotionally charged situations and direct the calls.
Although a nice organisation, advisor roles become somewhat menial quite quickly.

pros:
Great friendly environment, with opportunity to learn across a myriad of areas i.e. Housing, employment, benefits etc. 
Hands on work, which enables you to improve your research and people skills.
cons:
Although they are independent from the government, they take contracts from the government, which tends to set arbitrary/unrealistic KPI's. This may lead to stress on employees. 
This particular branch pays low wages for same role and amount of work, other branches pay considerably more.
They also do not hire often, so pressure is mounted on existing employees on smaller projects that can do with more employees in order to meet KPI'S/ demand.
If you have an area of advice you would like to go into, you are more likely to be sidelined/siphoned into projects and areas not of your interest, for quite some time, whilst being promised otherwise.

Provides advice services on a range of issues to the local community, often those who are the most marginalised and unable to access services elsewhere.

Due to pandemic, organisation is in the process of transformation on how to deliver the service effectively to the community.
cons: Funding is a combination of local government and government contracts, grants from local organisations and fund raising. As a result, there can be regular reviews of jobs, hours and contracts for paid staff.

job_title: Administration Officer in Ash, South East England, England
pros:

cons: I don't have any cons- I personally really enjoyed working here

review_title: Wouldnt wish it upon my worst enemy.
pros:
Good pension but this job will make you depressed so you might not even make it to 65.
People that work there are generally nice.
cons:
I would honestly score this place -1 if it was possible. 

Sexist management - expressing disinterest in employing females as they 'have too much time off'

No room for growth - if there is room for growth within the organisation it is very limited. 

Team leaders are stretched - workload for each team leader seemed intense and expectations are over and above considering that the teams are about 10-12 people to share one manager - leads to lack of one to ones and therefore less chance of growth. 

Expected to work overtime if needed - they will not reimburse you either financially or by giving time back if you are on a call past your working hours - if you feel like going above and beyond, dont bother. 

Which leads me on to my next point.... Lack of recognition. 
Lack of recognition - no interest in providing recognition to congratulate staff on handling tricky calls (including suicidal clients). 

Toilet breaks - Ah toilet breaks.. it goes without saying that in any other contact centre role, you will be allocated specific time for toilet breaks which do not encroach on your personal rest time off the phones. Unfortunately, cannot say the same for CA - have to take time out of your breaks to nip to the loo, so unless you have an extremely strong bladder, this may not be the role for you.

General role is monotonous - dealing with the same enquiries every day, little to no variation in methods of working (eg. webchat one day, phones on the next). 
Clients can also be very rude (not CA fault but something to keep in mind). 

No social aspects to the role - socials at CA used to be ok (and that is being generous) however since the pandemic there has been no focus on team building exercises and the company feels very split, managers are not interested in building relationship with their teams.

Sick pay not included in package. 

Management can be hard to approach due to lack of rapport/relationship between managers/team leaders and call handlers.

Systems used are useless/temperamental - do not be surprised if you have to manually input data into the system after a phone call with a client as Flare (system used by consumer team) is constantly failing - can lead to a more stressful day - Management seem to have no interest in improving the systems they use, despite feedback from call handlers. 

Finally, and probably the most detrimental aspect to the organisation, is the lack of diversity within the team - working in the Caerphilly office illustrated this - I cannot think of one non-white person that has been employed whilst I worked there - shocking, really.

If the above does not hinder your view on this organisation then the role will be perfect for you. Good luck, you will need it!

This is all my opinion based on observation whilst working here.

pros: A Handful of good advisors, flexible working
cons: Poorly Managed, Cliquey, Poor advice, toxic environment

cons: I joined Citizens Advice from another national charity where I was nurtured as someone with much to give and solid experience. I saw Citizens Advice as a career move but from the outset there was poor staff morale, high staff turnover and little development for older employees who were on their second career. I moved to another organisation after Citizens Advice and was almost immediately promoted but the experience really knocked my self confidence which was disappointing.

review_title: Good employer, diverse & dedicated staff, pay is stagnating.
job_title: Advice Session Supervisor in Mansfield, England
pros:
Structured E learning per role, regional class based training is great. Staff and volunteers want to make a difference, you can be an individual! Theres a keeness to retain staff after they have trained and understand advice, recording and QAA rather than a high turnover. Many years of service by most staff! Would recommend even if it is only a short contract!
You fight for the little guy.
You learn new things every day.
You make a difference.
cons:
No money in the sector, inevitable short term contracts. Essential roles need to be covered no matter how small the CA so staff often have a range of extra responsibilities to meet brand partnership expectation. No payrises, pay is stagnating over the years due to lack of funding for advice services. 
Universal Credit, ESA and PIP create a demand for advice any CA struggles to keep up with!!
Stark reality of a decade of austerity measures is plain to see.

job_title: Generalist Adviser ( Post Qualified) and Money Adviser in Folkestone, England
pros:
Learnt to be a proper generalist adviser to AQA audit standards.
Learnt to do short precise write up's referencing everything I  say not just on the top of my head from Adviser net, CPAG and Disability Rights handbook. 
Learnt to do proper PIP and ESA claims, MR and Appeals and first tier tribunals. 
Learnt to be a proper money adviser. 
The two supervisors have 18 years experience and I've learnt so much I really admire them both professionals one I clashed with but she bent me to her way of thinking.
cons: Some of the horrible clients what do you say when a three year old child spits at you and tells you to using an expletive where to go ,  you can't blame the child it's the parent's fault for bringing the child up like that.

Change for changes sake, to much  box ticking and paperchasing  .Gradual erosion over the past few years of the Generalist advisers role.  De skilling of highly skilled generalist advisers to down to the role of Gateway assessors.
Poor management and admin. Nepatism, paid jobs going to applicants with none or little knowledge of the Citizens advice service including training officers who have never worked in Citizens advice or trained as advisers.
Employing Advice session supervisers with far less knowlege and experience than the volunteers they are supposed to support

job_title: Rights Guide Volunteer in Hammersmith, England
pros: Meeting the other volunteers and being able to do something for others.
cons: Not supported very much. I worked a number of shifts on my own with limited support from anyone as supervisors were overworked and they didn't take on a paid member of staff in the reception area. Expected to commit to 6 months which I did, I received a negative response from the Volunteer Development Manager when I decided to move on and seek paid work. I know from my own experience and from others that we felt like we were doing actual work without receiving much recognition or appreciation.  Often we felt stressed.

pros: You are given excellent training, colleagues are all decent, helpful and supportive people who genuinely care about their work. The work is always exciting and challenging and you are encouraged to push yourself to take on higher resposibilities. I've got a sense of my abilities being appreciated and being encouraged to grow with adequate support should I struggle.
cons: Sometimes there are a lot of clients and few assessors so there is pressure to get through clients quickly.

review_title: Risks of renovating a Victorian Mansion
job_title: Service Delivery, Design and Development in London, England
pros: Citizens Advice (HQ) walked the walk on generous staff benefits and especially rights. Salaries were competitive, it has a quality modernised office in central london. It was one of the first major charities to ambitiously embrace and invest in digital transformation. It is a household brand and has a national footprint. It was doing well to turn itself around from a difficult funding period. Strong commitment from local CABs. National brand and big potential to influence policy and support local citizens with problems. Moneysavingexpert Martin Lewis a fan.  It was trying to head in the right direction in difficult times with some successes.
cons: Working at Citzens Advice often felt like renovating a much loved Victorian Mansion whilst living in it - installing broadband, double glazing and solar panels, into a classic old structure and features but often hiding dodgy floorboards, peeling plaster and rising damp. When I was there it was very split between two sides of the organisation. On one hand the older staff teams, methods, ways of working akin to best and worst of local and national government. Their good work often getting washed up in the politics of hierarchy, length of service and status retention. On the other side a new heavily invested-in digital design team and new outcome focused policy team given full backing and support to move forward fairly quickly - focused on user-need, agile working, It often felt like being in the middle of a quiet, polite civil war with lots of scheming and anxiety.

job_title: Witness Service Team Leader in Peterborough, England
pros: Good training. Lots of E-Learning. Really good ethos and focus of three behaviours: Inventive; Generous; and Responsible. Get to make a positive impact on many people's lives. Generally speaking, really nice colleagues. Approachable management.
cons: Communication can be incredibly lax between different teams. Change is not always communicated effectively. IT systems are poor and there is little training on how to use said IT. Funding is pretty bad. Inconsistency between areas. Not a lot of room to progress.

pros:
As a volunteer I learnt about many problems in the community which most of us are not aware of and the best part is that the staff train us how to advice people on such issues. It's a relaxed environment and staff are always around to help you.

If you want to be a good lawyer, its probably the first step you need to take. Helps you to understand if you like listening to such problems, advising and researching  on many issues, which are all the basic skills of a lawyer.
cons: nothing really!!! It's a place where people help each-other.

pros:
Helping people sort out their problems, making a difference.
Good working atmosphere, whilst it lasted.
Talented people, for the most part.
Not much else.
cons:
Culture of blame within the organisation encouraged by senior directors.
Lying to staff and bureaux
misrepresenting of facts
Closing offices out of spite/punishment for perceived failures.
No career opportunities exist as any progression would be seen as a target to be used as a scapegoat.

pros: Easy going flexible management and straight forward slick supervisors make for a well functioning work environment. Enabling you to do the job well, while giving you confidence in the bureau understanding your own personal plans. The roles are naturally sociable, though office chatter is fairy limited - but there are lulls in calls sometimes. Thumbs up from me.
cons: You don't work at the bureau for the money generally, a handful of employees are paid the rest are volunteers - the paid mostly being full time. Though this isn't important if your a volunteer.

job_title: Work In Central Office in London, England
pros: Committed group of talented people, and a really strong brand which can serve as a great platform to campaign on important problems. The bureaux are really let down by an inefficient central structure and management
cons:
Very distant CEO and management team that are responsible for a really poor management culture. There's a very distrustful relationship between staff and employees, and very poor morale. 

Executive team do not always take decisions in a consistent and meritocratic way. 

Very poor use of public funds and a real disconnect between stated values and actual ways of working. 

I've seen so many people be dragged underwater here, it's a horrible culture

pros: on going training and the staff are very friendly keeping up the legislation changes and being able to challenge on the clients behalf where necessary. Gathering ebef for the bureau
cons: i have not found any downside to the bureau apart from not enough funding to employ volunteers who would like to work on a permanent basis

review_title: Not enough  funding or appreciation for volunteers
pros: Fantastic  place to work where you're  exposed to a vibrant  working environment  and professional  development.
cons: CAB does not pay for lunch or travel  cost if coming from very far. No financial incentive  to attend work. Lots of incompetent/lazy paid workers relying  on voluntary staff to do all the dog work!

review_title: enjoy it as i get to meet new clients everyday

cons: There is very little opportunity to get a paid position, so it can be frustrating when you know there is no job opportunites

pros: Decent salary, little in the way of expectation, no requirement to work outside of office hours.
cons: Constant restructure, totally opaque organisation structure, shambolic management. If you're someone who thrives on achievement, this is the wrong place for you. If you like to sit around doing very little while pulling in a decent salary, put in an application!

review_title: Overall enjoyed it but it had its quirks
pros: Very well-paid as far as the charity sector goes, people genuinely lovely and I made friends for life there, work interesting and varied.
cons: Culture at times a bit bizarre - the top protect themselves and it can be hard to break through if you're more junior. Tension between national/local, the former had too much money it didn't know what to do with it all.

job_title: Volunteer in Cobham, Surrey, South East England, England
pros: The training is brilliant! Helps you learn exactly what is needed for the job. I started as information assistant now i am an assessor.
cons: Sometimes there are not any clients in the bureau, this makes it a little bit boring however we are allowed to use our phones, and bring books.

pros: Genuinely full of impressive people who are dedicated to what they do. Diverse roles and lots of room for development of your career.
cons: With such a large footprint it can be difficult to know what the organisation is up to. Strategic objectives not always clear.

review_title: A real eye opener, great experience.
pros: A real eye-opener, a great experience. It taught me a lot about dealing with people from different cultures and backgrounds. No day was the was the same, people who arrive at citizens advice are often in crisis, therefore requiring delicate handling to ensure they receive the right help. Very rewarding.
cons: None, for the type of organisation it is very well run, providing communities with valuable support and volunteers with fantastic experience.

pros: I feel I wasted my time and can't think of any pros.
cons:
I was accepted for training after interview with Wiltshire which is separate from Swindon, without even telling me that I had to find a local office to work in myself. I had to get up at 7am to catch buses and train to get 20 miles away for training. 
I'm qualified in law and I always thought that knowing your legal rights are a basic human right and shouldn't be only for those who can afford it, so that was my motivation for volunteering. I felt as if I could be helpful to others.
There was one teacher on her own in training centre. One class was about how even in domestic abuse cases, if the police ask questions about the victim then we can't say anything. I don't think she had any real legal training, because I remembered that the law had changed so that even if a victim drops an abuse case under pressure, the police can carry on with the prosecution, so for no other reason than wanting to learn and find out their procedures I asked what we do if we feel a victim's life is in danger, which I thought was a good question, and she said we still can't give any information about the victim. I told her that I understood and accepted that, thinking that was the end of the matter. 
Then at the end of the class she said she was concerned that I wouldn't be discreet, going into detail about how her sister had been in an abusive relationship. I said I was just trying to learn about what we're supposed to do, and thought she understood me explaining a second time about why I asked, wondering why she needed to give personal details about her sister away. She didn't seem very professional with discretion. Other times she would go into details about her other sister use has asperger's syndrome, to a classroom of people she didn't know, so if anybody wasn't discreet it was her. 
It wasn't until I had a few weeks of training that they told me I had to phone up myself to find an office to volunteer in. I phoned up an office who didn't seem to want anybody new but said to go in. First day I got there it seemed as if they didn't want me there. I wasn't shown around or told what to do. No clients came in and I just had to sit there being bored, Then 5 mins before office closed they said I could sit in with an advisor who had just finished training herself. She was a bit odd as didn't seem interested in helping me with my first day or helping me to feel at ease when I was asking questions about what to do. I told adviser I was nervous as hadn't sat in with a client before thinking she would help me, but she just ignored me, so I went into the room with her and the client was talking to her but also kept looking at me so I didn't want to be rude and smiled and nodded at her. Then after we walked out of the room I said to the adviser that I had been nervous sitting in for the first time ever, but instead of helping me she started stomping around and went to the manager to say I had talked to the client, when I just didn't want to appear rude when she was looking at me.
It was an awful experience and I wasted my time for nothing. They were unprofessional and in with each other. I can see now why the CAB was useless when I had been to them for advice before I started legal training.

pros:
Supported to progress
Fair wage
Open culture
Management open to feedback 
Feel involved - even at a lower level 
Supported through any issues rather than criticised
cons: Honestly, none.  Great place to work and would recommend to any friend looking for employment if a suitable role was available.  If I had to put something, it would be lack of a bonus scheme, but this is understandable as it’s a charity.

pros: You get to meet people from a variety of backgrounds, you are challenged to really push yourself to offer a quality service, the staff at CA are all amazing people with a wealth of knowledge to offer.
cons: Can be stressful at times and your hard work may not always be appreciated by clients, this comes with the territory in a position like this however.

pros: Teamwork, worked using my own initiative, multi-tasker and I really enjoyed my time there.
cons: There are no cons, that I can think of. I enjoyed my time there immensely.

pros: Lovely clients who were a pleasure to help; the volunteers were great too.

review_title: Great employer, be part of something!
